awd_titl_txt: ABR: Melding Mathematical and Theoretical Models of Stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
The stress response is a major mechanism of resilience. However, even after nearly 100 years of studying stress we still lack a rigorous predictive model that allows us to know what the impact of stressors on individuals and populations might be. The lack of such a model is a long-standing roadblock to our understanding of the ecology and pathophysiology of stress responses.  This project will create and test the first quantitative predictive model of stress pathophysiology.  The foundation will be the Reactive Scope Model, a graphical model of stress.  A central component of this graphical model is that prolonged activation of a stress response creates wear-and-tear.  Here a mathematical model of stress based upon wear-and-tear will be constructed and integrated with laboratory studies using captive birds as models. Overall, the project will generate a new predictive quantitative model for how individuals, and by extension populations of individuals, will respond to stressors. The creation of an integrated conceptual and quantitative theory will provide the foundation to resolve long-standing questions in stress physiology and open up novel areas of research.  This project will provide training of students at all levels.  Specific activities will recruit women and minority students to research positions. Cross-disciplinary training will teach these students how to integrate physiological and quantitative techniques. A weekly research blog by research students will incorporate the research into an introductory Endocrinology class, thereby providing a research focus to a lecture class. The work will be disseminated through publications in the research literature and presentations to the general public. 

Technical Abstract
The quantitative model will consist of a system of nonlinear partial differential equations that captures the dynamics of the Reactive Scope conceptual model. Using two established stress and stress response protocols, introduction to captivity and rotating intermittent stressors applied to captive birds, numerical solutions to deterministic approximations suggested by the Reactive Scope model will be tested against empirical experimentation.  The key goal will be to understand the temporal dynamics of wear-and-tear.  Predicted timing and effects of an individual bird's responses to wear-and-tear will be assessed in four ways: alterations in glucocorticoid function by measuring plasma hormone concentrations and glucocorticoid receptor dynamics; attenuation of sympathetic nervous system responses by measuring heart rate and heart rate variability; changes in behavior by measuring overall activity levels and responses to novel objects; and increases in homeostatic instability by measuring DNA damage as evidenced by changes in telomere length and cellular DNA fragmentation.   The laboratory results will guide iterative alterations to the quantitative model, indicate new experimental designs based upon the updated quantitative model, and form revised predictions for subsequent laboratory tests of stress and wear-and-tear.

por.por_cntn:
The stress response is a major mechanism of resilience. However, even after nearly 100 years of studying stress we still lack a rigorous predictive model that allows us to know what the impact of stressors on individuals and populations might be. The lack of such a model is a long-standing roadblock to our understanding of the ecology and pathophysiology of stress responses.  This project created and tested the first quantitative predictive model of stress pathophysiology.  The foundation was the Reactive Scope Model, a graphical model of stress; central to this graphical model is that prolonged activation of a stress response creates wear-and-tear.  We constructed a quantitative model consisting of a system of nonlinear integro-differential equations that captured the dynamics of the Reactive Scope conceptual model.  This is the first quantitative predictive model of stress ever constructed.  We then used empirical experimentation utilizing two established stress and stress response protocols, introduction to captivity and rotating intermittent stressors applied to captive birds, to determine numerical solutions to deterministic approximations suggested by the Reactive Scope model. We further tested wear-and-tear predictions derived from the quantitative model in four ways: alterations in glucocorticoid function by measuring plasma hormone concentrations; attenuation of sympathetic nervous system responses by measuring heart rate and heart rate variability; changes in behavior by measuring overall activity levels and responses to novel objects; and increases in homeostatic instability by measuring DNA damage as evidenced by changes in telomere length and cellular DNA fragmentation.  The results from the empirical testing matched well the predictions derived from the quantitative predictive model.  Consequently, the creation of this quantitative model provides the foundation to resolve long-standing questions in stress physiology and opens up novel areas of research.  We are now able to generate predictions for how individuals, and by extension populations of individuals, will respond to stressors.

 

This project provided training at all levels.  Specifically, 3 postdoctoral fellows, 12 graduate students, and 16 undergraduates participated in project activities. Of the 12 graduate students, 7 were co-authors on 31 papers.  Of the 16 undergraduates, 9 were co-authors on 10 papers. The project provided extensive cross-disciplinary training to teach these students how to integrate physiological and quantitative techniques.  We presented many of our research techniques and outcomes by producing a weekly research blog, written by research students, that described the process and outcomes of their individual projects.  These research blogs were then incorporated into an introductory Endocrinology class at the time of writing, thereby providing a contemporaneous research focus and experience to a large lecture class. Furthermore, our work was disseminated through 34 publications in the research literature (with 6 more in submission and several more projects being prepared for publication) as well as presentations to the general public.
